trans-unit.source: Create a record set and records for a DNS Zone | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a record set and records for a DNS Zone | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to create host records for Azure DNS.Setting up record sets and records using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to create host records for Azure DNS.Setting up record sets and records using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Create DNS records
trans-unit.target: Create DNS records

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Azure Powershell steps
trans-unit.target: Azure Powershell steps

trans-unit.source: After creating your DNS Zone, you need to add the DNS records for your domain.
trans-unit.target: After creating your DNS Zone, you need to add the DNS records for your domain.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you first need to understand DNS records and record sets.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you first need to understand DNS records and record sets.

trans-unit.source: Understanding record sets and records
trans-unit.target: Understanding record sets and records

trans-unit.source: Each DNS record has a name and a type.
trans-unit.target: Each DNS record has a name and a type.

trans-unit.source: A _fully qualified_ name includes the zone name, whereas a _relative_ name does not.
trans-unit.target: A _fully qualified_ name includes the zone name, whereas a _relative_ name does not.

trans-unit.source: For example, the relative record name ‘www’ in the zone ‘contoso.com’ gives the fully qualified record name ‘www.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: For example, the relative record name ‘www’ in the zone ‘contoso.com’ gives the fully qualified record name ‘www.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In Azure DNS, records are specified using relative names.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In Azure DNS, records are specified using relative names.

trans-unit.source: Records come in various types according to the data they contain.
trans-unit.target: Records come in various types according to the data they contain.

trans-unit.source: The most common type is an ‘A’ record, which maps a name to an IPv4 address.
trans-unit.target: The most common type is an ‘A’ record, which maps a name to an IPv4 address.

trans-unit.source: Another type is an ‘MX’ record, which maps a name to a mail server.
trans-unit.target: Another type is an ‘MX’ record, which maps a name to a mail server.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS supports all common DNS record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV and TXT.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS supports all common DNS record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV and TXT.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, you need to create more than one DNS record with a given name and type.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, you need to create more than one DNS record with a given name and type.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose the www.contoso.com web site is hosted on two different IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose the www.contoso.com web site is hosted on two different IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: This requires two different A records, one for each IP address:
trans-unit.target: This requires two different A records, one for each IP address:

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a record set.
trans-unit.target: This is an example of a record set.

trans-unit.source: A record set is the collection of DNS records in a zone with the same name and the same type.
trans-unit.target: A record set is the collection of DNS records in a zone with the same name and the same type.

trans-unit.source: Most record sets contain a single record, but examples like the one above in which a record set contains more than one record are not uncommon.
trans-unit.target: Most record sets contain a single record, but examples like the one above in which a record set contains more than one record are not uncommon.

trans-unit.source: (Records sets of type SOA and CNAME are an exception, the DNS standards do not permit multiple records with the same name for these types.)
trans-unit.target: (Records sets of type SOA and CNAME are an exception, the DNS standards do not permit multiple records with the same name for these types.)

trans-unit.source: The Time-to-Live, or TTL, specifies how long each record is cached by clients before being re-queried.
trans-unit.target: The Time-to-Live, or TTL, specifies how long each record is cached by clients before being re-queried.

trans-unit.source: In the above example, the TTL is 3600 seconds or 1 hour.
trans-unit.target: In the above example, the TTL is 3600 seconds or 1 hour.

trans-unit.source: The TTL is specified for the record set, not for each record, so the same value is used for all records within that record set.
trans-unit.target: The TTL is specified for the record set, not for each record, so the same value is used for all records within that record set.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure DNS manages DNS records using record sets.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure DNS manages DNS records using record sets.

trans-unit.source: Create record sets and records
trans-unit.target: Create record sets and records

trans-unit.source: In the following example we will show how to create a record set and records.
trans-unit.target: In the following example we will show how to create a record set and records.

trans-unit.source: We'll use the DNS 'A' record type, for other record types see [How to manage DNS records](dns-operations-recordsets.md)
trans-unit.target: We'll use the DNS 'A' record type, for other record types see [How to manage DNS records](dns-operations-recordsets.md)

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Create record set and assign to a variable $rs:
trans-unit.target: Create record set and assign to a variable $rs:

trans-unit.source: The record set has relative name ‘www’ in the DNS Zone ‘contoso.com’, so the fully-qualified name of the records will be ‘www.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: The record set has relative name ‘www’ in the DNS Zone ‘contoso.com’, so the fully-qualified name of the records will be ‘www.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: The record type is ‘A’ and the TTL is 60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The record type is ‘A’ and the TTL is 60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a record set in the apex of the zone (in this case, 'contoso.com'), use the record name "@", including the quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a record set in the apex of the zone (in this case, 'contoso.com'), use the record name "@", including the quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: This is a common DNS convention.
trans-unit.target: This is a common DNS convention.

trans-unit.source: The record set is empty and we have to add records to be able to use the newly created "www" record set.
trans-unit.target: The record set is empty and we have to add records to be able to use the newly created "www" record set.

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Add IPv4 A records to the "www" record set using the $rs variable assigned when created record set on step 1:
trans-unit.target: Add IPv4 A records to the "www" record set using the $rs variable assigned when created record set on step 1:

trans-unit.source: Adding records to a record set using Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig is an off-line operation.
trans-unit.target: Adding records to a record set using Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig is an off-line operation.

trans-unit.source: Only the local variable $rs is updated.
trans-unit.target: Only the local variable $rs is updated.

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Commit the changes to the record set.
trans-unit.target: Commit the changes to the record set.

trans-unit.source: Use Set-AzureDnsRecordSet to upload the changes to the record set to Azure DNS:
trans-unit.target: Use Set-AzureDnsRecordSet to upload the changes to the record set to Azure DNS:

trans-unit.source: The changes are complete.
trans-unit.target: The changes are complete.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the record set from Azure DNS using Get-AzureDnsRecordSet:
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the record set from Azure DNS using Get-AzureDnsRecordSet:

trans-unit.source: You can also use nslookup or other DNS tools to query the new record set.
trans-unit.target: You can also use nslookup or other DNS tools to query the new record set.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] As when creating the zone, if you have not yet delegated the domain to the Azure DNS name servers you will need to specify the name server address for your zone explicitly.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] As when creating the zone, if you have not yet delegated the domain to the Azure DNS name servers you will need to specify the name server address for your zone explicitly.
